articles.headline: Canada to Pay Millions in Indigenous Lawsuit Over Forced Adoptions
articles.snippet: A 1960s government program took indigenous children from their families and put them up for adoption by nonnative parents.
articles.abstract: A 1960s government program took indigenous children from their families and put them up for adoption by nonnative parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — For decades, Canadian social workers forcibly separated indigenous children from their families, putting them up for adoption by nonnative families in Canada and around the world.

articles.headline: Company Scrambles as Weinstein Takes Leave and a Third of the Board Resigns
articles.snippet: The moves came as employees and business partners of the company voiced concern about sexual harassment allegations, revealed in a New York Times investigation.
articles.abstract: The moves came as employees and business partners of the company voiced concern about sexual harassment allegations, revealed in a New York Times investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our Live Coverage and Updates of the Harvey Weinstein verdict.]
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Trump Administration Rolls Back Birth Control Mandate
articles.snippet: New rules vastly expand religious exemptions from an Obama-era requirement for employers to include birth control coverage in their health insurance plans.
articles.abstract: New rules vastly expand religious exemptions from an Obama-era requirement for employers to include birth control coverage in their health insurance plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday moved to expand the rights of employers to deny women insurance coverage for contraception and issued sweeping guidance on religious freedom that critics said could also erode civil rights protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Small Investors Support the Boards. But Few of Them Vote.
articles.snippet: Figures indicate individual stockholders prefer the status quo in corporate boardrooms and on governance matters. Don’t believe it, experts say.
articles.abstract: Figures indicate individual stockholders prefer the status quo in corporate boardrooms and on governance matters. Don’t believe it, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Institutional investors have been flexing their muscles on corporate governance issues this year. So why do individual investors continue to be so disengaged on these matters?

articles.headline: Political Unrest Threatens Spain’s Return to Economic Vigor
articles.snippet: Just as the country seemed to be recovering, the referendum has made investors wary, and prompted banks and businesses to move out of Catalonia.
articles.abstract: Just as the country seemed to be recovering, the referendum has made investors wary, and prompted banks and businesses to move out of Catalonia.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Those inclined to the view that no price can be placed on freedom have presumably missed the action in the Spanish bond market.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Rachel Chaundler

articles.headline: After 78 Killings, a Honduran Drug Lord Partners With the U.S.
articles.snippet: Devis Leonel Rivera Maradiaga led a brutal drug gang that ferried tons of cocaine north. Then he approached the Drug Enforcement Administration for a deal.
articles.abstract: Devis Leonel Rivera Maradiaga led a brutal drug gang that ferried tons of cocaine north. Then he approached the Drug Enforcement Administration for a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, HONDURAS — The number of murders the Honduran drug lord admitted to orchestrating over 10 years was stunning.
articles.byline: By Joseph Goldstein and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: ‘My Stomach Dropped’: Harrowing Night for Twin Brothers of the Las Vegas Police
articles.snippet: As Sergeant Branden Clarkson helped direct officers responding to the mass shooting, he learned his brother, a detective, had been shot in the neck.
articles.abstract: As Sergeant Branden Clarkson helped direct officers responding to the mass shooting, he learned his brother, a detective, had been shot in the neck.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — It was the first overtime shift Detective Casey Clarkson had worked in four years. But he wanted the money and he figured a country music festival would be fun.

articles.headline: Germany’s Shift to Green Power Stalls, Despite Huge Investments
articles.snippet: The country has spent about $222 billion on renewable energy subsidies, often from higher electricity bills. But emissions are stuck at roughly 2009 levels.
articles.abstract: The country has spent about $222 billion on renewable energy subsidies, often from higher electricity bills. But emissions are stuck at roughly 2009 levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETZIGAU, Germany — Katharina Zinnecker’s farm in the foothills of the German Alps has been in the family since 1699. But to squeeze a living from it today, she and her husband need to do more than sell the milk from their herd of cows.

articles.headline: Global Economy’s Stubborn Reality: Plenty of Work, Not Enough Pay
articles.snippet: Even as job markets are tight in many major economies, low unemployment is failing to spur robust increases in wages, leaving workers angry.
articles.abstract: Even as job markets are tight in many major economies, low unemployment is failing to spur robust increases in wages, leaving workers angry.
articles.lead_paragraph: LILLESTROM, Norway — In the three-plus decades since Ola Karlsson began painting houses and offices for a living, he has seen oil wealth transform the Norwegian economy. He has participated in a construction boom that has refashioned Oslo, the capital. He has watched the rent climb at his apartment in the center of the city.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jonathan Soble

articles.headline: Americans Jailed After Failed Coup in Turkey Are Hostages to Politics
articles.snippet: U.S. officials appear powerless to secure their release, and the dozen detainees may be bargaining chips in Turkey’s attempts to have Fethullah Gulen extradited.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials appear powerless to secure their release, and the dozen detainees may be bargaining chips in Turkey’s attempts to have Fethullah Gulen extradited.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATAY, Turkey — One is a NASA scientist who was vacationing with relatives in Turkey. Another is a Christian missionary who has lived in Turkey for 23 years. Others include a visiting chemistry professor from Pennsylvania and his brother, a real estate agent.

articles.headline: Hoping to Have Trump Cleared, Legal Team Eases Resistance to Inquiry
articles.snippet: President Trump’s aides, who once debated a scorched-earth strategy, hope the special counsel on Russia will give the president the public exoneration he has long sought.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s aides, who once debated a scorched-earth strategy, hope the special counsel on Russia will give the president the public exoneration he has long sought.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials once debated a scorched-earth strategy of publicly criticizing and undercutting Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating Russian efforts to disrupt last year’s election. Now, President Trump’s lawyers are pursuing a different course: cooperating with the special counsel in the hope that Mr. Mueller will declare in the coming months that Mr. Trump is not a target of the Russia inquiry.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Who Was Stephen Paddock? The Mystery of a Nondescript ‘Numbers Guy’
articles.snippet: The Las Vegas gunman was a savvy businessman and an absentee neighbor who lived on his own terms, according to people who knew him.
articles.abstract: The Las Vegas gunman was a savvy businessman and an absentee neighbor who lived on his own terms, according to people who knew him.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Stephen Paddock was a contradiction: a gambler who took no chances. A man with houses everywhere who did not really live in any of them. Someone who liked the high life of casinos but drove a nondescript minivan and dressed casually, even sloppily, in flip-flops and sweatsuits. He did not use Facebook or Twitter, but spent the past 25 years staring at screens of video poker machines.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise, Serge F. Kovaleski and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: The ‘Resistance,’ Raising Big Money, Upends Liberal Politics
articles.snippet: The tug of war between establishment and upstart forces foreshadows a reorganization of the left that could reshape the Democratic Party’s ideology.
articles.abstract: The tug of war between establishment and upstart forces foreshadows a reorganization of the left that could reshape the Democratic Party’s ideology.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It started as a scrappy grass-roots protest movement against President Trump, but now the so-called resistance is attracting six- and seven-figure checks from major liberal donors, posing an insurgent challenge to some of the left’s most venerable institutions — and the Democratic Party itself.

articles.headline: Hosting Proms and Selling Cows: North Korean Embassies Scrounge for Cash
articles.snippet: Desperate for hard currency to keep their operations afloat, diplomats from the so-called hermit kingdom smuggle liquor, drugs, cars and guns — and engage in more mundane activities.
articles.abstract: Desperate for hard currency to keep their operations afloat, diplomats from the so-called hermit kingdom smuggle liquor, drugs, cars and guns — and engage in more mundane activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — While the embassies of most countries promote the interests of companies back home, North Korea’s are in business for themselves.

articles.headline: ISIS Fighters, Having Pledged to Fight or Die, Surrender en Masse
articles.snippet: More than 1,000 militants turned themselves in after the latest in a string of humiliating defeats in Iraq and Syria. Many claim to have been only cooks or clerks.
articles.abstract: More than 1,000 militants turned themselves in after the latest in a string of humiliating defeats in Iraq and Syria. Many claim to have been only cooks or clerks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIBIS, Iraq — The prisoners were taken to a waiting room in groups of four, and were told to stand facing the concrete wall, their noses almost touching it, their hands bound behind their backs.

articles.headline: Disney’s Big Bet on Streaming Relies on Little-Known Tech Company
articles.snippet: BamTech has had success with its services for Major League Baseball, HBO and others. Disney is hoping the company can do the same for it.
articles.abstract: BamTech has had success with its services for Major League Baseball, HBO and others. Disney is hoping the company can do the same for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: For two days in late June, Disney’s board of directors gathered at Walt Disney World in Florida to wrestle with one topic: how technology was disrupting the company’s traditional movie, television and theme park businesses, and what to do about it?
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin

articles.headline: Bob Corker Says Trump’s Recklessness Threatens ‘World War III’
articles.snippet: The powerful Republican senator’s remarks in an interview capped a remarkable day of sulfurous insults between him and the president.
articles.abstract: The powerful Republican senator’s remarks in an interview capped a remarkable day of sulfurous insults between him and the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bob Corker, the Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, charged in an interview on Sunday that President Trump was treating his office like “a reality show,” with reckless threats toward other countries that could set the nation “on the path to World War III.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Mark Landler

articles.headline: An Epic, and Costly, Boardroom Battle at Procter & Gamble
articles.snippet: An activist investor, Nelson Peltz, is trying to shake up a storied company in what is viewed as a warning shot to other blue-chip firms.
articles.abstract: An activist investor, Nelson Peltz, is trying to shake up a storied company in what is viewed as a warning shot to other blue-chip firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate board elections are usually dull affairs best left to investor newsletters and government filings.

articles.headline: The Economy Is Humming. Bankers Are Cheering. What Could Go Wrong?
articles.snippet: As global policy makers meet in Washington for the International Monetary Fund’s biannual meetings, the global economy is thriving.
articles.abstract: As global policy makers meet in Washington for the International Monetary Fund’s biannual meetings, the global economy is thriving.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the global economy has been defined by dissonance.

articles.headline: White House Makes Hard-Line Demands for Any ‘Dreamers’ Deal
articles.snippet: The long list of proposals imperiled a fledgling bipartisan push to reach a legislative solution to give legal status to the young undocumented immigrants.
articles.abstract: The long list of proposals imperiled a fledgling bipartisan push to reach a legislative solution to give legal status to the young undocumented immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Sunday delivered to Congress a long list of hard-line immigration measures that President Trump is demanding in exchange for any deal to protect the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers, imperiling a fledgling bipartisan push to reach a legislative solution.

articles.headline: Harvey Weinstein Is Fired After Sexual Harassment Reports
articles.snippet: The Weinstein Company’s board announced Mr. Weinstein’s firing on Sunday, days after The New York Times reported on decades of harassment allegations.
articles.abstract: The Weinstein Company’s board announced Mr. Weinstein’s firing on Sunday, days after The New York Times reported on decades of harassment allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Weinstein Company fired its co-founder Harvey Weinstein on Sunday, after a New York Times investigation uncovered allegations that he had engaged in rampant sexual harassment, dealing a stunning blow to a producer known for shaping American film and championing liberal causes.

articles.headline: Russians in Silicon Valley Can’t Shake Hacking’s Shadow
articles.snippet: While headlines about election interference have bolstered their tech reputation, many find themselves the target of jokes and even suspicion.
articles.abstract: While headlines about election interference have bolstered their tech reputation, many find themselves the target of jokes and even suspicion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pavel Cherkashin, a Russian investor based in this city, thought he had the perfect name for a Catholic church that he is spending $11.5 million converting into a tech palace. It would be called Hack Temple.

articles.headline: For Disney’s Iger, an Unlikely Political Turn
articles.snippet: After the company he runs feels the president’s wrath, Robert Iger does not say no to a possible White House run.
articles.abstract: After the company he runs feels the president’s wrath, Robert Iger does not say no to a possible White House run.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Before the Trump presidency, who could have imagined that the Walt Disney Company would find itself at the fiery center of the American political debate?

articles.headline: Stephen Miller, the Powerful Survivor on the President’s Right Flank
articles.snippet: Mr. Miller, who was a conservative trapped in a liberal California high school, has rocketed to the upper reaches of White House influence, especially on immigration.
articles.abstract: Mr. Miller, who was a conservative trapped in a liberal California high school, has rocketed to the upper reaches of White House influence, especially on immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Stephen Miller had their attention. That was reason enough to keep going.

articles.headline: Wall Street Firms Gambled on Puerto Rico. They’re Losing.
articles.snippet: Investors in real estate racked up big financial losses. Some are lobbying for federal aid that would help Puerto Rico — and their bottom lines.
articles.abstract: Investors in real estate racked up big financial losses. Some are lobbying for federal aid that would help Puerto Rico — and their bottom lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days after Hurricane Maria leveled Puerto Rico, John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, boarded his company’s 23-seat Bombardier jet and flew to San Juan.

articles.headline: Nobel in Economics Is Awarded to Richard Thaler
articles.snippet: Professor Thaler is an expert in behavioral economics and is a professor at the University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business.
articles.abstract: Professor Thaler is an expert in behavioral economics and is a professor at the University of Chicago’s Booth School of Business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Richard H. Thaler, whose work has persuaded many economists to pay more attention to human behavior, and many governments to pay more attention to economics, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences on Monday.

articles.headline: California Fires Kill at Least 10 and Destroy 1,500 Buildings
articles.snippet: Mass evacuations were ordered in what is being called one of the most destructive fire emergencies in the state’s history.
articles.abstract: Mass evacuations were ordered in what is being called one of the most destructive fire emergencies in the state’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest news on the wildfires, please read this story.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Jonah Engel Bromwich and Maggie Astor
